body:
Currently running macOS Catalina and NeoVim fails to start with error:

"‚Äúnvim‚Äù can‚Äôt be opened because its integrity cannot be verified."

That's running: `./nvim-osx64/bin/nvim` after having run install instructions:

> Download nvim-macos.tar.gz
> Extract: tar xzvf nvim-macos.tar.gz
> Run ./nvim-osx64/bin/nvim

Was working in macOS Mojave. Have downloaded and followed the install again but problem persists.

Anyone have any idea why this might be?

comment_data.body: Catalina (still a prerelease, by the way!) has once again stepped up security, this time to cover even unsigned terminal programs. After you get the error message, you can try looking in the `Security & Privacy` preference pane; sometimes it mentions the blocked program there and allows you to make an exception for it. (To be repeated for every downloaded library that binary links to...)

Hmm. What's the process for signing OSS binaries on macOS? Do we have to register with a cert authority ? Can it be automated in CI?

Edit: see also https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5433#issuecomment-486724845

Unfortunately, signing is no longer enough, you also need to get it notarized: https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=09032019a, see also https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/notarizing_your_app_before_distribution/resolving_common_notarization_issues as well as https://www.update.rocks/blog/osx-signing-with-travis/

(@qvacua had some choice words for that in relation to VimR, if I recall correctly. Seems it takes ages. This might only concern framework apps, though, not command-line programs.)

As a workaround, binaries you build yourself are considered safe; in particular, `brew install neovim` still works without problem on Catalina (at least when building from source; haven't looked at the bottles in a long time. You need to have the corresponding beta of the XCode command line tools installed.)
Ah. That‚Äôs no problem then. I‚Äôll just install with brew instead. Thanks üôè
@benfrain Make sure you look at the pinned issue about updating the `libvterm` dependency, then!
The notarization using the `altool` is faster now. However, unfortunately, it still prevents me to fully automate the release process...

> I am still having this problem, is there an update to this anytime soon? Thanks

There's a reason the `help wanted` label is on this issue.  From the links earlier in this issue, it looks like someone in the project needs to pay to get an Apple developer ID and then we could automate it.

I'm not sure if anyone already has one, but I'm sure we would welcome a PR that provides the infrastructure to do the signing/notarizing which we could then plug the relevant details into.

> But the most recent version is NVIM v0.5.0-dev+nightly-374-gfe1ebea33 which is not enough for me.

You're joking, right?  That _is_ the most recent commit in the repository right now.

@jamessan I thought most recent version is _NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1012-gfe1ebea33_ but probably 374 number is for macOS and 1012 is for linux. (on my linux I have 1012). If yes that means I have a lot of problem with newest neovim nightly version and plugins such as coc.nvim, gitsigns.nvim and treesitter after last update. I thought it's because neovim isn't the newest one. On Linux I don't have any of those problems with newest neovim and newest version of this plugins so it's probably on macOS only :/ Anyway if this is the most recent version thanks for info.

@ecosse3 Please check the pinned issue and try the remedies (especially reinstalling LuaJIT from source). In any case, your issue is unrelated to notarization.

(By the way, the relevant bit is at the end `gfe1ebea33`, which is the hash of the -- in this case latest -- commit you are building from. Everything else is added by the build script and depends on the environment, so you can usually ignore it.)

> From the links earlier in this issue, it looks like someone in the project needs to pay to get an Apple developer ID and then we could automate it.

Mentioning it here to raise awareness, anybody interested in notarized builds can help by [sponsoring](https://github.com/sponsors/neovim) the project.

Since it's not mentioned here yet, I'll mention the macos bypass method in case it helps someone.

Find the nvim binary in finder -> right click -> open. It'll give you the warning but allow you click open instead of just moving it to trash. It'll still complain about libintl.8.dylib also being unsigned. Find the dylib in the neovim folder (under libs), also right click -> open. These will add it to the exception list after which you can open neovim regularly from the terminal.

It doesn't solve what this issue is about and you'll need to re-do the steps every time you pull down a new version but I figured there might be people not familiar with macos enough. Maybe devs can put a warning about this in the installation instructions?

> Find the nvim binary in finder -> right click -> open. It'll give you the warning but allow you click open instead of just moving it to trash. It'll still complain about libintl.8.dylib also being unsigned. Find the dylib in the neovim folder (under libs), also right click -> open. These will add it to the exception list after which you can open neovim regularly from the terminal.

For the libraries, I believe it's also possible after the first complaint to open the Security Preferences Pane; on the first tab, there should now be a button to grant access to all recently denied libraries. (It's been a while, though, so I don't remember the full details, and it might have changed in recent macOS versions.)
guys in MacOS, pressing CTRL ,click with the right button over the nvim icon, then click in open, a modal will be displayed asking if you want to add an exception, click yes and that is!!!...

I had this problem macOS Monterey **‚Äúnvim‚Äù cannot be opened because the developer cannot be verified.** After adding iTerm.app / Terminal.app to **Developer Tools** as shown below it works.

Go to **System Preferences...** then click on **Security & Privacy**,  at the top select **Privacy** tab, and by the left look for **Developer Tools**, then at the bottom click on the lock to open for edit. 

In the  section by the right where it says **Allow the apps below to run software locally that does not meet the system's security policy** check to see if your terminal is in the list, if it's there but unchecked then then check it, otherwise at the bottom click on  the **+** sign to add your terminal by selecting it from your **Applications**

**System Preferences...** -> **Security & Privacy** -> **Privacy** tab -> **Developer Tools**

I hope this will help someone.

If you're having problems with libintl.8.dylib with `brew install neovim-nightly`:

```
xattr -dr com.apple.quarantine /opt/homebrew/Caskroom/neovim-nightly/latest/nvim-osx64/libs/libintl.8.dylib
```

This removes quarantine on the lib

I too am facing the same issue, and I can't even allow it from settings as the MacBook is provided by my company with a lot of restrictions.

If there could be a signed release it would be great, Seeing this issue being open for 2 years now, I'm limiting my hopes.

github just announced Artifact Attestations: 
https://github.blog/2024-05-02-introducing-artifact-attestations-now-in-public-beta/

> Artifact Attestations is powered by [Sigstore](https://github.blog/2022-10-25-why-were-excited-about-the-sigstore-general-availability/), an open source project for signing and verifying software artifacts.

That may not directly solve the issue for macOS, but it could set the foundation for a long-term solution.

Note from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/28610#discussioncomment-9330900 : 

> The Homebrew .pkg installer is now signed similar AFAICT to the link you posted. See https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/pull/15743#issue-1818316215 . I believe they automate it through GitHub.

labels.description: packaging and distributing Nvim to users
labels.name: distribution

milestone.description: Low priority. Not planned for the current target, may be reassigned.
milestone.title: backlog

title: macOS binary: sign, notarize
